steps.title: Order your wood.
steps.content: Order your wood. If the framing for the building will be 2x6, allowing fewer members and deeper insulation, you will need a 2x6 sill plate. Since sill plates have an indoor application, 'pressure treated' wood is not necessary. For almost half the cost you can get a termite-treated board called 'borate'. It's apple-green, but will eventually weather to gray.

steps.title: Cover the wood with a tarp.
steps.content: Cover the wood with a tarp. The sun will warp and twist your boards all over the place - especially something as wet as borate.

steps.title: Measure the distance for the sill plate with a tape measure.
steps.content: Measure the distance for the sill plate with a tape measure.

steps.title: Cut the length of board - use a handsaw or a circular saw.
steps.content: Cut the length of board - use a handsaw or a circular saw.

steps.title: Place the cut board into position on top of the J bolts.
steps.content: Place the cut board into position on top of the J bolts. Typically, sill plates are laid flush with the outside edge of the stem wall or slab. This is so water will not collect on an exposed lip of concrete and migrates into the dwelling. However, if it seems counterintuitive to you to put the full weight of the building on the outside of the stem wall, rather than the center of it, just make sure the sheathing and siding that goes on above will fully overlap the foundation.

steps.title: Get the board secure (have someone hold one end of the board, or prop it up with objects), and use a marker to trace around the top of the bolts beneath the board.
steps.content: Get the board secure (have someone hold one end of the board, or prop it up with objects), and use a marker to trace around the top of the bolts beneath the board. Marker is better than pen, because it's awkward to draw around the bolt at this angle, and a marker will give you a nice line to follow.

steps.title: Drill the holes for the bolts.
steps.content: Drill the holes for the bolts. Go a little bigger with the holes. If the bolts are 1/2", drill a 5/8" hole. This will make it far easier to get the board down over the bolts. Washers beneath the nuts will cover any gaps. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Lay down seam sealer.
steps.content: Lay down seam sealer. This is a strip of foam that goes down beneath the sill plate. It makes a better seal and provides insulation, and further protects the board. The foam is cut to fit and pressed down over the bolts. 'Seam sealer' is inexpensive - a 50' roll will be around $4 - $5. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Install the board down over the bolts.
steps.content: Install the board down over the bolts. As long as you left exposed at least 2 1/2" of J bolt above the block, or your boards happen to be perfectly flat, the bolts should stick up beyond the sill plate enough to get the washer and nut on. However, if your boards are warped, you're going to have to weigh down the board on either side of the bolt. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Gouge around the bolt into the board if you still can't get the nut on.
steps.content: Gouge around the bolt into the board if you still can't get the nut on. A flathead screwdriver will do the job.

steps.title: Tighten the nuts down over the washers and board.
steps.content: Tighten the nuts down over the washers and board. Since treated wood is wet, don't over tighten. It's easy to start grinding down into the board. Tighten it so it's hard to screw down any further, but it's not driving down into the wood. [5] X Research source
